text: Hello, I have trouble starting up a Julia notebook with Jupyter extension in vs Code. When using the 1.0.10 language server the language server is stuck on starting. When I go back to version 1.0.8 as it's suggested in some GitHub issues of the vscode julia extension, I still cannot connect to a kernel.

elements.text: Hello, I have trouble starting up a Julia notebook with Jupyter extension in vs Code. When using the 1.0.10 language server the language server is stuck on starting. When I go back to version 1.0.8 as it's suggested in some GitHub issues of the vscode julia extension, I still cannot connect to a kernel.

text: If you run "Focus on output view" from the command palette and select "Julia Language Server" from the dropdown you might get some error messages which could offer a hint

elements.text: If you run "Focus on output view" from the command palette and select "Julia Language Server" from the dropdown you might get some error messages which could offer a hint

text:
I solved it by adding IJulia via:

] add IJulia

now VS Code finds a kernel to start.
<https://github.com/JuliaLang/IJulia.jl#quick-start>

> I still cannot connect to a kernel
Ah sorry I missed this part. If you want to use the built-in Jupyter notebook functionality of VSCode then yea, you'd need IJulia. Note in case you didn't know though that julia-vscode alone doesn't need this, you can do inline evaluation of your Julia files without an IJulia kernel, eg

elements.text: I still cannot connect to a kernel

Ah sorry I missed this part. If you want to use the built-in Jupyter notebook functionality of VSCode then yea, you'd need IJulia. Note in case you didn't know though that julia-vscode alone doesn't need this, you can do inline evaluation of your Julia files without an IJulia kernel, eg

text: (also note if you like Jupyter stuff, its much nicer on the VSCode insiders edition, much of that hasnt made it to the stable version yet)
